name: Hydrogen
quirkyFact: The most abundant chemical substance in the universe!

name: Helium
quirkyFact: Known for making your voice high-pitched when inhaled (don't try this at home!).

name: Lithium
quirkyFact: Used in batteries for your phone and electric cars.

name: Beryllium
quirkyFact: Found in emeralds, giving them their green color!

name: Boron
quirkyFact: A key ingredient in Borax and heat-resistant glass like Pyrex.

name: Carbon
quirkyFact: The backbone of all known life, found in diamonds and graphite!

name: Nitrogen
quirkyFact: Makes up about 78% of Earth's atmosphere!

name: Oxygen
quirkyFact: We literally can't live without it! Used in breathing and fire.

name: Fluorine
quirkyFact: The most reactive chemical element, it can even burn water!

name: Neon
quirkyFact: Gives neon signs their distinctive orange-red glow!

name: Sodium
quirkyFact: Explodes violently when put in water, but is in table salt!

name: Magnesium
quirkyFact: Burns with a brilliant white light, often used in fireworks!

name: Aluminum
quirkyFact: The most abundant metal in Earth's crust, lightweight and recyclable!

name: Silicon
quirkyFact: The main component of sand and basis for computer chips!

name: Phosphorus
quirkyFact: Comes in white (glowing!) and red (matches!) forms.

name: Sulfur
quirkyFact: Smells like rotten eggs but is vital for life!

name: Chlorine
quirkyFact: A greenish-yellow gas used to purify water and bleach.

name: Argon
quirkyFact: Used in double-paned windows and old light bulbs to prevent oxidation.

name: Potassium
quirkyFact: Essential for banana's health benefits and reacts violently with water!

name: Calcium
quirkyFact: Makes your bones strong and found in chalk and limestone!

name: Scandium
quirkyFact: Used in aerospace components and some sports equipment.

name: Titanium
quirkyFact: Strong as steel but much lighter, used in aircraft and implants.

name: Vanadium
quirkyFact: Used to make tough steel alloys for tools and armor.

name: Chromium
quirkyFact: Gives rubies their red color and makes stainless steel shiny!

name: Manganese
quirkyFact: Essential for plants and used to decolorize glass or make it purple!

name: Iron
quirkyFact: The main component of steel and found in your blood!

name: Cobalt
quirkyFact: Used to make powerful magnets and gives a deep blue color to glass.

name: Nickel
quirkyFact: Used in coins, batteries, and to make stainless steel rust-resistant.

name: Copper
quirkyFact: An excellent conductor, used in wiring and plumbing for centuries!

name: Zinc
quirkyFact: Protects steel from rust (galvanizing) and crucial for your immune system.

name: Gallium
quirkyFact: Melts in your hand! Used in semiconductors and LEDs.

name: Germanium
quirkyFact: An important semiconductor material, used in fiber optics.

name: Arsenic
quirkyFact: Infamous for being a potent poison, but also used in semiconductors.

name: Selenium
quirkyFact: Can convert light into electricity, used in solar cells and photocopiers.

name: Bromine
quirkyFact: The only nonmetal element that is a liquid at room temperature.

name: Krypton
quirkyFact: Used in some types of lights and makes a 'flash' when used in lasers.

name: Rubidium
quirkyFact: So reactive that it will ignite spontaneously in air!

name: Strontium
quirkyFact: Gives fireworks a beautiful crimson red color!

name: Yttrium
quirkyFact: Named after Ytterby, a village in Sweden, which has 4 elements named after it!

name: Zirconium
quirkyFact: Highly resistant to corrosion, used in nuclear reactors and surgical instruments.

name: Niobium
quirkyFact: Used in superconducting magnets and jet engines.

name: Molybdenum
quirkyFact: An essential trace element for life, also used in steel alloys.

name: Technetium
quirkyFact: The first element to be artificially produced, no stable isotopes exist!

name: Ruthenium
quirkyFact: One of the rarest elements in Earth's crust, used to harden platinum alloys.

name: Rhodium
quirkyFact: The most expensive non-radioactive metal, used in car catalytic converters.

name: Palladium
quirkyFact: Can absorb up to 900 times its own volume of hydrogen gas!

name: Silver
quirkyFact: The best conductor of electricity among all metals.

name: Cadmium
quirkyFact: Used in rechargeable batteries, but is quite toxic.

name: Indium
quirkyFact: So soft it can be cut with a knife and leaves a mark on paper.

name: Tin
quirkyFact: When bent, it makes a characteristic 'tin cry' due to crystal twinning.

name: Antimony
quirkyFact: Used in cosmetics since ancient times and in fire retardants.

name: Tellurium
quirkyFact: Its compounds can give you a garlic-like breath odor!

name: Iodine
quirkyFact: Essential for thyroid hormones and turns purple when heated.

name: Xenon
quirkyFact: Used in flash lamps and some powerful headlights, glows blue!

name: Cesium
quirkyFact: The most reactive of all metals, ignites in air and water.

name: Barium
quirkyFact: Gives fireworks a vibrant green color!

name: Lanthanum
quirkyFact: Starts the lanthanide series; used in camera lenses and lighter flints!

name: Cerium
quirkyFact: The most abundant rare-earth metal, used in self-cleaning ovens!

name: Praseodymium
quirkyFact: Used to make yellow-orange glass for welder's goggles.

name: Neodymium
quirkyFact: Used to make incredibly strong magnets and purple-colored glass.

name: Promethium
quirkyFact: The only radioactive lanthanide, used in luminous paints.

name: Samarium
quirkyFact: Used in high-temperature magnets and to treat cancer.

name: Europium
quirkyFact: The most reactive rare-earth element, used in TV screens for red color.

name: Gadolinium
quirkyFact: Used in MRI contrast agents and some computer memories.

name: Terbium
quirkyFact: Used in energy-efficient light bulbs and hard drives.

name: Dysprosium
quirkyFact: Has the highest magnetic strength of any element at room temperature.

name: Holmium
quirkyFact: Used to make strong magnets and calibration standards for spectrophotometers.

name: Erbium
quirkyFact: Used in fiber optic communication and creates pink colors in glass.

name: Thulium
quirkyFact: The rarest of the lanthanides, used in portable X-ray devices.

name: Ytterbium
quirkyFact: Used in high-stability atomic clocks and some surgical lasers.

name: Lutetium
quirkyFact: The last of the lanthanides, used in catalysts and PET scans.

name: Hafnium
quirkyFact: Used in nuclear reactor control rods because it absorbs neutrons well.

name: Tantalum
quirkyFact: Highly corrosion-resistant, used in surgical implants and mobile phones.

name: Tungsten
quirkyFact: Has the highest melting point of all elements, used in light bulb filaments.

name: Rhenium
quirkyFact: One of the densest elements, used in high-temperature superalloys for jet engines.

name: Osmium
quirkyFact: The densest naturally occurring element, twice as dense as lead!

name: Iridium
quirkyFact: The most corrosion-resistant metal, found in meteorites.

name: Platinum
quirkyFact: Extremely rare and valuable, used in jewelry and catalytic converters.

name: Gold
quirkyFact: It's so ductile, a single ounce can be stretched into a 5-mile-long wire!

name: Mercury
quirkyFact: The only metal that is liquid at room temperature, but it's toxic!

name: Thallium
quirkyFact: Highly toxic, once used as a rat poison and insecticide.

name: Lead
quirkyFact: Used in plumbing in ancient Rome, hence 'plumbing' from 'plumbum' (Latin for lead).

name: Bismuth
quirkyFact: The most naturally diamagnetic metal and has a beautiful iridescent oxide layer.

name: Polonium
quirkyFact: Discovered by Marie Curie, it's highly radioactive and used as a source of alpha particles.

name: Astatine
quirkyFact: The rarest naturally occurring element, less than a gram exists in Earth's crust at any time.

name: Radon
quirkyFact: A radioactive gas that can accumulate in homes, dangerous if inhaled.

name: Francium
quirkyFact: The second rarest naturally occurring element, with a half-life of only 22 minutes.

name: Radium
quirkyFact: Discovered by Marie Curie, it glows in the dark and was once used in watches.

name: Actinium
quirkyFact: Starts the actinide series, highly radioactive and used in research.

name: Thorium
quirkyFact: A radioactive element that can be used as a nuclear fuel.

name: Protactinium
quirkyFact: One of the rarest and most expensive naturally occurring elements.

name: Uranium
quirkyFact: The primary fuel for nuclear reactors and bombs.

name: Neptunium
quirkyFact: The first transuranic element, discovered in 1940.

name: Plutonium
quirkyFact: Used in nuclear weapons and as a power source for spacecraft.

name: Americium
quirkyFact: Found in household smoke detectors.

name: Curium
quirkyFact: Named after Marie and Pierre Curie, discovered in 1944.

name: Berkelium
quirkyFact: Named after Berkeley, California, where it was discovered.

name: Californium
quirkyFact: One of the most expensive elements, used in neutron sources.

name: Einsteinium
quirkyFact: Named after Albert Einstein, discovered in debris from a nuclear test.

name: Fermium
quirkyFact: Named after Enrico Fermi, also discovered from nuclear test debris.

name: Mendelevium
quirkyFact: Named after Dmitri Mendeleev, creator of the periodic table.

name: Nobelium
quirkyFact: Named after Alfred Nobel, founder of the Nobel Prizes.

name: Lawrencium
quirkyFact: Named after Ernest Lawrence, inventor of the cyclotron.

name: Rutherfordium
quirkyFact: Named after Ernest Rutherford, the 'father of nuclear physics'.

name: Dubnium
quirkyFact: Named after Dubna, Russia, a center for nuclear research.

name: Seaborgium
quirkyFact: Named after Glenn T. Seaborg, a Nobel-winning chemist.

name: Bohrium
quirkyFact: Named after Niels Bohr, Nobel-winning physicist.

name: Hassium
quirkyFact: Named after the German state of Hesse, where it was discovered.

name: Meitnerium
quirkyFact: Named after Lise Meitner, pioneering nuclear physicist.

name: Darmstadtium
quirkyFact: Named after Darmstadt, Germany, where it was discovered.

name: Roentgenium
quirkyFact: Named after Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen, discoverer of X-rays.

name: Copernicium
quirkyFact: Named after astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus.

name: Nihonium
quirkyFact: Named after 'Nihon', one of the two ways to say 'Japan' in Japanese.

name: Flerovium
quirkyFact: Named after Russian physicist Georgy Flyorov.

name: Moscovium
quirkyFact: Named after the Moscow Oblast region in Russia.

name: Livermorium
quirkyFact: Named after the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in the USA.

name: Tennessine
quirkyFact: Named after the state of Tennessee, a center for heavy element research.

name: Oganesson
quirkyFact: The heaviest known element and very unstable. Only a few atoms have ever been made!
